sn47.37:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.37:1.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:1.4: As they do so they give up desire for the body.
sn47.37:1.5: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:2.1: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:2.2: As they do so they give up desire for feelings.
sn47.37:2.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:3.1: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:3.2: As they do so they give up desire for the mind.
sn47.37:3.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.
sn47.37:4.1: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.37:4.2: As they do so they give up desire for principles.
sn47.37:4.3: When desire is given up they realize the deathless.”
